citation.article-title: Reclassification of Aurantimonas altamirensis (Jurado et al. 2006), Aurantimonas ureilytica (Weon et al. 2007) and Aurantimonas frigidaquae (Kim et al. 2008) as members of a new genus, Aureimonas gen. nov., as Aureimonas altamirensis gen. nov., comb. nov., Aureimonas ureilytica comb. nov. and Aureimonas frigidaquae comb. nov., and emended descriptions of the genera Aurantimonas and Fulvimarina
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Aureimonas (Au.re.i.mo′nas. L. adj. aureus golden; Gr. fem. n. monas a unit; N.L. fem. n. Aureimonas golden-coloured bacterium).
Cells are Gram-reaction-negative, short rods of mean size 1.0×2.0µm.
Growth occurs at 4–40 °C (optimum 25–30 °C) and in 0–3 % (w/v) NaCl.
Cells are catalase-, urease- and oxidase-positive but negative for l-alanine-aminopeptidase.
Positive for hydrolysis of DNA and starch, but negative for hydrolysis of tyrosine, Tween 80 and casein.
Cells are able to assimilate glucose, l-arabinose, d-mannitol and malic acid.

Negative for nitrite reduction, production of indole from tryptophan, fermentation of glucose, arginine dihydrolase activity, hydrolysis of β-glucosidase and assimilation of capric acid, N-acetylglucosamine, trisodium citrate and phenylacetic acid.

Positive for utilization of d-arabitol, l-arabinose, i-erythritol, d-fructose, l-fucose, d-galactose, α-d-glucose, inositol, d-mannitol, d-mannose, d-psicose, l-rhamnose, d-sorbitol, xylitol, acetic acid, adonitol, formic acid, d-gluconic acid, β-hydroxybutyric acid, succinic acid, bromosuccinic acid, l-alanyl-glycine, hydroxy-l-proline and l-proline.
The major respiratory lipoquinone is Q10.
Polar lipids comprise DPG, PME, PC, PG, PE, two lipids, two unidentified aminolipids and SQDG.
The predominant fatty acid is C18 : 1ω7c with significant proportions of C16 : 0, C18 : 1 2-OH, C18 : 1 and cyclo-C19 : 0ω8c.
Members of the genus have been isolated predominantly from non-marine habitats.
The genus comprises three species Aureimonas altamirensis, Aureimonas ureilytica and Aureimonas frigidaquae.
The type species is Aureimonas altamirensis.
